text: Pours a cloudy/hazy yellowish orangish golden color with fizzy white head that dissipates quickly. Tartness, funk, wheat, oak, and grass on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with funk, tart citrus, and dry.

375ml bottle from the brewery. Murky orange, large fizzy offwhite head, good retention. Aroma of oak, white grape, apricot, dandelion, funk, musty mold. Taste is bright apricot, white grape, pepper, strong funk. Thin-medium bodied, high carbonation, very strong lingering tartness.

From notes. Enjoyed at a bottle share at Seans on December 29. 375 mL bottle. The pour is a nice cloudy golden yellow with a thicker white head that slowly dissipates, leaving no lace. The aroma is really funky up front. There is a light tart fruitiness, a strong dusty barnyard to it, and a little horse blanket on the finish. Its interesting, and not quite what I would call a gueuze. Its close, but not quite. The flavor is much of the same. There is a woodiness to it in addition to the funk. The barnyard kicks up a little more and drowns out the tart fruitiness. The horse blanket exists on the finish with a little sweatiness. The mouth feel is lighter and pretty crisp with a lingeringly funky and lightly spicy finish. Its really dry and not as tart as I would hope. Interesting beer.
From a 375 ml bottle purchased at the brewery. Pours a cloudy gold. Funky farmhouse aroma. Flavors of vinyl, some caramel and horse blanket. As weird as it sounds, this is a really nice beer.

Sample at Zwanze Day 2016 at Jolly Pumpkin. Aroma is funk, tart, cat piss, barnyard, horse blanket. Appearance is golden, mostly clear, off white head. Taste is sweet, funky, cat piss, barnyard, good. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, crisp, funky cat piss aftertaste. Overall, this is pretty solid.
Bottle at Culmination Fest 16: Poured a murky orange with white head. Aroma is very woodsy and oak, some funk. Taste is very funky and tart with wood being most prevalent along with acidic.

375 ml bottle @ Nacht van de Grote Dorst 2016. Unclear, pale golden body with a rather small white head. Aroma is tart, funky, acidic, lemon and some wood. Pretty classic but less pronounced than a small bunch of Belgium Geuze thats present at the table. Flavor is also a bit milder than the Belgium samples, but very refined and smooth. Its the real deal, but still a rather different experience. Mild acidity, smooth fruit, wood, mild funk, balanced acidity. Very nice, glad to finally have the opportunity to taste one of the most authentic lambic based brew outside Belgium.
Trübes goldenes Bier mit mittelgroßen weißen schaumkrone. Geruch sehr sauer, holzig, helle Früchte. Geschmack sehr sauer, helle Früchte, kraut.
Hazy yellow color with white head. Aroma is sour, lacto, wood. Taste is sour lacto, barrel, some booze. High carbonation. Sourer than most Lambics. Good, but not excellent.

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks Amit. 2015 bottle. Cloudy shiny yellow. Great aroma of barnyard, cobwebs, sweat, oak, fresh fruits, light vinegar note. Sour flavor, dry, fresh, funky, fruity, oaky, kinda lemony. Medium-bodied. Great stuff, feels authentic.

Had the privilege to drink this back to back with 3 Fonteinen Oude Gouze. This was a bit more muscular, woodier, especially right out of the bottle, but settled in to a nice tart lemon-lime experience.
Bottle. Golden hazy pour with some head. Nice naturally funky, fruit, apricot aromas. Nice acetic sour Flavors, fruit, wine, oak and naturally tart tones.

Notes, from many bottles on many occasions. This is a heck of a lambic that stands right there with the best that come out of Belgium. Its a full-on celebration of funk and wild yeast -- sour with barnyard funk, leather, musty smell, and some citrus flavor and biscuity malt. Major respect to Allagash for keeping the traditional methods going. I cant get enough of this beer.
Sampled from bottle thanks to kermis. Hazy yellow color, small white head. Smell and taste dusty, dry, lemony and sourish with some tart fruitpeel. Decent body and carbonation. Decent.

Bottle shared. Pours cloudy blonde light orange with a ring white head. Aroma of dusty funk, light leather notes and citrus. Flavour is moderate sour. Light to medium bodied with above light prickly carbonation.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis. Poured a hazy straw colour with a thin broken white head. The aroma is dry yeast, sugar, acid. The flavour is moderate sour with a crisp fresh sharp acid citrus doughy yeast palate. Light bodied with lively carbonation.

Pours a nice vibrant yellow orange, white head and nice carbonation. Aroma is big oak, must, barnyard, musty citrus, earth. Flavor is musty oak, citrus, vinegar, med acidity. Carbonation is great, med sour and light body. Lovely
Honey colored pour with minimal white head. Smell is lambic and some sulfur and - am I right - baby diapers? Flavor is sulfuric lemons. Nice tartness. Im digging it.

375 mL bottled April 3rd, 2014, drunk 11/19/15, thanks to my friends John and Sara.Encouraging pour shows a brassy-golden liquid. Good clarity and well-carbonated with a white head atop that slowly fades to cover/ring. Not tons of sediment left behind in the bottle, which is a bit surprising given it being kept in the fridge for a year, but whatever.Soft, understated funk in the nose immediately makes good on its promise of emulating true lambics. Light wood/oak character is a little bit more perceptible here than in most of the real guys, but its not in any big quantity here and is certainly still enjoyable. B. Lambicus like cherry pie and deep, complex, sweaty, horsey funk. Some light black and white pepper phenols and no alcohol or flaw.Excellent and subtle in the mouth. Its neither heavily sour, yet nor does it come across as cheap or rushed. Soft oak, cheese, yogurt and lots of cherry and horse blanket. Tight carbonation. Passes most of the "Is this an excellent, authentic lambic?" tests, but Im a bit concerned with a somewhat moderate amount of what tastes either like adjunct sugar fermentation or oxidation. Seems hard to believe it would be either but nonetheless, there is something very slightly off-putting. Bitter vanilla-meets-cork-meets-candi sugar is about the best I can do to describe it. Whatever the case, the beer is still excellent and a truly impressive feat by Allagash. Really hope to try the other Coolships eventually.

November 5, 2015. Bottle, bottled april 4, 2015. Shared by Carl, thanks! 
Light hazy small white head. Aroma is funky, minerals, some citrus, cheese and hints of barnyard. Taste is tart funky and some share mineral notes. Finish is dry, minerally, grains, barnyard notes, some citrus and apples. Light bodied, soft to average carbonation, somewhat astringent.

Bottle courtesy of Carl. Pours tiny hazy golden with a small frothy offwhite head that doesnt leave much trace while dissipating. Smell is sour and tiny fruity with crackers, lemon juice, lime juice, yoghurt, hay, dry soil, barnyard and lemon zest. Taste is sour and funky. Mouthfeel is dry, tart and light to medium bodied. Finish is sour with crackers, lemon juice, lime juice, yoghurt, dry soil, hay, minerals, leather, barnyard and lemon zest. Solid but simple gueuze...
A: Ligt Yellow/orange, thin lacing. N: Cheese, grape, apricot T: Wood, hops O: Very carbonated and quite bitter...

Sampled at GABF 2015. Yellow in the tasting glass. No head. Nose of funk. Lots of funk. Medium body. Flavor is funky. Again a huge amount of funk, The long and the short of it is that this is a damn good beer.

Enjoyed at Freetail Bottleshare 2015... Lots of tart lemons funk and horse blanket... A great american gueuze, hope I can find my own bottle... Simply delicious

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Beautiful beer, nice lemon, tart nose. Funky barnyard with great lemon zest effervescence . Fantastic sour by Allagash!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
June Ale Alpharetta. Sharp tart funky lemon, some of that horse blanket shows up, fizzy. Nice gueze from the States. Not overly complex, but good stuff.

30 May 2015, tap at Firestone Walker Invitational Beer Festival. Yellow clear no bubbles. Nose is gorgeous! Funky and tart! Thin body and moderately fizzy. Funky, tart, woody. Wow. Just wow! Tart woody finish.

Shared at Ale Alpharetta, brought by Hamp. Cloudy yellow, with a thick, off-white ring. Big nose of lemon peel, hard cheese, and chalk. Nicely tart, and a touch of citrusy sweetness. Medium body, hard, crisp, and clean. This is a sharp, clean, limbic. Not bad.
Pours hazy golden with a thick eggshell head. Aroma is strong, sour and fruity. Flavor is fruity and quite sour, with a hint of malt. Mouthfeel has decent body and fizz.

bottle, from brewery. bottled Jan 19 2015. good aroma, Lemon/grapefruit, cheese yeast, kind of coriander. clean golden orange color, ok head and lace. medium sour flavor. light body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, bitter sour finish that lingers. its nice. flavor and finish best parts, aroma good, but mellow. I left sediment in bottle for appearance good stuff.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Tap at FWIBF 2015. Pours a light, clear yellow with soft white head. Aroma is slightly horse blanket funk with a nice sour nose. Taste was a very complex citrus and funk blend with grapefruit and lemon rind. Nice American gueuze.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: (Embouteillée le 19 janvier 2015) Belle robe jaune qui mousse en blanc. Beaux parfums boisés et citronnés avec, il me semble, dautres fruits à chair jaune. Houblons surannés qui transpirent de légers arômes fromagés. Cest sublime mais cela natteint pas tout à fait le niveau des grandes de ce monde. Les saveurs vont dans le même sens : bons microbes, chêne ou autre bois, fruits acides. Beau corps léger avec un pétillement tranquille. Finale peu agressive mais longue, boisée et surette. Si facile à boire. Merci Youri!

Très belle Gueuze dégustée par un après-midi ensoleillé. Sûrette à souhait et fraîche comme on les aime, cette bière parfaitement fidèle au style possède tous les attributs dune authentique Gueue Belge. Cest vraiment à sy méprendre! On y décèle de la pommette verte non mûrie, de lécorce ce citron et du bois. Un petit côté salin est même présent, ce qui contribue à la grande buvabilité de la bière. Magnifique longueur en bouche et ponctuée dune belle touche boisée et légèrement vineuse, la bière est tout indiquée pour une dégustation au soleil! Félicitations à Allagash qui a su recréer avec beaucoup de savoir-faire, une Gueuze à limage des autorités Belges en la matière!
Pours clear gold some head lots lacing. Nose tart with some lemon. Flavours tart lots of lemon and grapefruit. Taste bit sour light sweet. Medium body light carbonation.

375 bottle. It pours a nice golden orange color with a fizzy but lasting white head. The aroma is really nice with striking citrus lemon and grapefruit, hints of tart apricots and nice soft hay and cheesy funk with some hints of vanilla. Very Gueuze like. The flavor is even better with more tart acidic grapefruit, orange and lemon with more hay and light cheesy funk. A little oak spice and vanilla in the finish. Perfectly tart and mouthwatering. The body is a bit fuller than you would expect from the style, but it adds a nice creaminess to the palate without compromising its crisp refreshing nature. Citrus fruit juice, particularly grapefruit juice for days... Nice soft funkiness. I absolutely loved this. A very rare successful American made Gueuze.

From the corked and caged green bottle. Murky, cloudy yellow-orange pour with a good sized head that fades back some. Pale malts are usurped by the sour characteristics of wild yeast and overripe fruit. An after-rain wood scent. The body is medium to better than medium. Sour and tart flavors abound and linger.

Bottle from bytemesis, thanks man! Hazy golden pour with tiny lacings. Nose has barnyard notes, citrus, oak, leather and green apples. Taste is funky, well balanced, cheesy, green apple skin, light citric, acidic, apricots, oaky notes and dusty.

Bottle thanks to Bursprak. 

Pours light orange with no head.

Aromas of sour green apples, nice bitterness, stable notes, barnyard, light leather, brett, apricots, citrus, floral notes.

Taste is apricots, citrus, barnyard, stable, brett, tart green apples, dust, dirt. Smooth and enjoyable!

Bottle thanks to Bursprak. Pours hazy yellow with a tiny white head. Aroma of horse blanket, weak floral notes, barnyard funk, leather, weak cheese, apricot/peachy fruity notes and some pear as well. The taste is quite funky and tart. Notes of wood, barnyard, vinegar, leather, citrus, some apples and floral notes. Pretty authentic to the style and pretty funky overall!
Bottle during RBWG. Pours a cloudy yellow with small off white head. The aroma is lemon, funk, oak. Thin mouth with tart lemon, light funk and barnyard, oak, very good.

37,5cl bottle thanks to Bursprak! Pours hazy yellow with a tiny, white head. Aroma has green apples, unripe pear, dusty funk, slight cheese, not particularly sour aroma, some citrus, floral spices and maybe some coriander, sweet, almost dry peach. Taste is surprisingly sour, dirty dusty, funky, some more peachy sweetness, but its style is very authentic belgian lambic style. Very dry finish. Medium carb and light body.

Tasted on 2/22/12 from a corked and caged 375mL bottle with Curtis and Paul. Pours cloudy peach orange with a thin white head that leaves thin, spotty lace. The nose is sour orange, chewable vitamin C, hay and barnyard funk. The flavor is more acidic citrus and orange peel bitterness with nice funk and sour chewable vitamin. The body is medium with just lighter than average carbonation and a long sour and bitter citrus peel finish.

Bottle, thanks to Levi. Pours hazy gold with offwhite head. Huge pop of cork, but liquid didnt move at all. Aroma of funk, basement, lemon juice, pepper (at the end), vinegar, and old lambic -- this shit actually makes me think Belgian lambic, which is a welcome surprise. Palate: Slick, oily texture. Medium body, average carbonation. Overall: Real nice.

375ml bottle, so many thanks to Chris for breaking this out at the end of our Seahawks NFC Championship game tasting. Creamy yellow. Gorgeous white fruity sour aroma. Rush of sweet sour. Creamy yeast. Tart citrus, lots of lemon juice on finish. Big lovely sour. Best Ive had in a long time, and a tribute to American brewers starting to get this right.

375 mL bottle at a tasting. Much thanks to Chris for sharing. Pours a cloudy pale yellow color with no head. What an awesome beer this is. A lot of lemon, strawberry, and blackberry aroma. Super tart flavor and finish. Incredible beer to say the least.
Bottle thanks to bytemesis. Nose is barny with a cheese kinda thing. Pour is hazy with a golden hue. Taste is earthy and oaky. Very good.
Bottle share thanks to Homer321. Hazy, straw yellow, no head. Funky, citrus, barnyard. Very tart, acidic, fair amount of oak character, finishes a bit bitter and lingering acidity.
Bottle, homer tasting. Pours hazy butterscotch, small white head, minimal lacing. Aroma is very oaky, funky, must, basement, a bit of cheese. Flavor is dry, oaky, medium funk. Light body, dry finish.

Poured from a 375 ml bottle with a bottle date of 5/25/2011. 
Aroma is full of an earthy, herbaceous funkiness with some light mustiness. Light citrus notes and acidity. Light vinegar and oak notes. Hints of tropical fruit and stone fruit. 
Pours a hazy golden orange with a small thin white head that quickly recedes to the edges. No lacing and faint to no legs. 
Flavor is not as nice as the aroma. Medium light acidity with both acetic and lactic character. Medium oak notes with quite a bit of herbal character but lacking the mustiness and funk. Moderate bitterness. Hints is stone fruit but again lacking compared to the aroma. 
Mouthfeel is medium light bodied with low carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, an alright beer but the aroma leads to a less enjoyable, though still nice flavor. It feel a bit too big and flabby in flavor and not as bright as in the aroma.

Bottle courtesy Chris R. Pours a still, clear straw color. Aroma funky, with some musty overtones and a bit of acetic character. Body slightly tart, long finish which has some tart notes of unripe pear. Impressive.
Grote dorst, straw 1 finger white head. Different kind of funky, hard to place, somewhat sweet. Flavor follows nose. Nice beer.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2014 Sample at GABF 10/03/2014, thanks to my sis for assistance with note-taking. Hazy orange color with a medium thin white head that dissipates steadily to a film. Short strings of lace. Aroma of funky fruit, oak and yeast. Medium body with flavors of funky citrus, yeast and wood. The finish is moderately sour with a tart citrusy aftertaste. Solid beer all around.

38cl, Vintage 2013, at 6.6%Vol, new exclusive American brew, thx alot to Secret Santa!, complex sour brew, sour/woody and slightly fruity, balanced, hazy, nearly no head, good brew, yet very expensive!

Bottle. Gold with a soapy head. Yeasty, peach, lactic, apricot, very slight green pepper note, even a hint of strawberry. Very complex. Amazing taste that constantly changes. Incredible mouthfeel that combines tartness and rich, almost sticky bitter notes. Wow. Awesome.

Bottle. Hazy gold with no head. Aroma is peach, apricot, funk and lactic notes. Taste is stunning. All of the notes from the aroma appear, plus a strong peppery note in the background, construction paper and strawberry. Medium mouthfeel, light carb, long finish and intense pucker action. This is one of the best beers I've had in a long time.

One of my 2015 GABF highlights. Very flavorful and well-made beer. Surprisingly clean, too. Pleasant funkiness in the background. Bright and snappy sourness. A fantastic gueuze and surely one of the best American-made spontaneously fermented beers I have ever had.

Pours a clear golden with big fluffy head. Smell is very minerally with some acidity and barnyard notes. Taste is similar. Not too sour and super dry. Easy drinking and a terrific American representation of a geuze 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle with dad- pours clear golden, lots of carbonation but little to no head. Nose of wet blanket, lemon, pear, oak. Loads of drying tartness, sour, farmyard funk, white grape , vinous. Damn good 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours hazy peach with a low white head. Aromas of yeasty rye bread, citrus, funk, honey. Taste is funk, citrus, honey, kiwi. Mouthfeel is very dry and tart. Stellar stuff.

Bottle: Muddled, unfiltered burnt orange-amber body with a slightly off-white head that fizzles away quickly into just a small collar. Wonderfully gueuze-like aroma. Lemon skin, sour stone fruits, lacto yeast, acetic underripe apricots, musty cork, funky cheese rind; huge amount of sweaty sock & barnyard funk in the back-end. Ripping sourness up front; lemon wedges, stone fruit, puckering lactic notes with citric undertones. Lovely lactobacillus sourness. Old corks, musty barnyard floors, & sweaty horseblanket thanks to the overload of brettanomyces. Pineapple, sour green apple, acidic; finishes with a pile of lightly tannic soured oak, sharp & dry as can be. Holy nutsack. Insanely delicious, maybe the best (& most authentic tasting) American attempt at a gueuze that I can recall. Dat FUNK.

(4/3/2014): Faudrait les avoir côte à côte mais jai limpression dêtre en présence dune gueuze 3F avec une présence dabricot mûr plus fraiche sur la langue...sinon le reste des paramètre me laisse croire que la flore bactérienne du Maine et des Flandres nest pas si différente finalement.

Sample @ Quitessence 2014. A côté de Cantillon, celle-là fait pâle figure. Presque pas de nez: légère acidité maltée peu amère avec relents de levure. Le corps malté manque de robustesse: légèrement acide petite rondeur developpant des arôme dargile, de grain acidulé. La fin est surette. Bière douce et fluette sans puissance.

Green bottle, 385 ml, bottled on 7/27/2011, savoured on June 25 2014; eye: orangey, hazy, no effervescence, tiny ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: green apple, acidity, sourness, wild yeasts, musk, woody; mouth: green apple, acidity, wild yeasts, light sourness, musk, light woody, semi-dry finale in wild yeasts with presence of musk, medium body, good carbonation, slick texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille verte, 375 ml, 6,6 %, embouteillée le 7/27/2011, savourée le 25 juin 2014; il : orangée, voilée, pas deffervescence, minuscule anneau de mousse beige, pas de dentelle; nez : pomme verte, acidité, aigreur, levures sauvages, musc, boisé; bouche : pomme verte, acidité, levures sauvages, légère aigreur, musc, léger boisé, finale semi-sèche en levures sauvages avec présence de musc, corps moyen, bonne carbonatation, texture coulante; en résumé : bien

Bottle at Grote Dorst. Light hazy golden liquid with medium white head. Aroma of apples, pears, funk, barnyard and mineral. Taste is dry and medium sour with notes of apple skin, lemon and funk. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. OK geuze but not elegant.

Shared bottle. 

Hazy amber.
Aroma: Mild funkiness for style. Less off-putting than usual.
Flavor: Fruity and complex taste starts sweet and sour but turns tart and bitter by the finish. Quite tart mid-taste. 

Very good and relatively low salt for style.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy golden/yellow color with a medium white head. A bi sour funky nose, oak. The favor is wonderful: tart aggressive sourness, a bit of barnyard funk, oaky tanins, dry, very fruity as well. Just an awesome sour.
Bottle. Pours a hazy golden color with a white head. Sour aroma of fruit,citrus, lemon, and oak. Flavor of lemon zest, citrus, mild funk, light acidity, oak and had a fairly dry oaky finish.
375ml bottle pours a light gold with a small bubble head. Tart apple lemon and slight oak taste.

Bottle shared at the Portland tasting, thanks 
Hazy white/pink with a small head and good lacing. Aroma is woody, sawdust and tart. Taste is tart fruit and woody 
Decent

Bottle sample from "hannont". Colour...light amber with a thin head. Nose...whoa! This smells like gooch, feet a d compost! Palate...delightfully tart and funky with a dry feel and a tart dryness. Theres plenty of orchard fruits, especially big ass pit fruits! The finish is quite nice and laced with kiwi and quince.

Hazy gold, white head. Nose is cheesy with lemon, horseblanket, unripe berries & hay. Flavor is lemon pith, earthy funk, woody & tannic. Ends up being a bit more bitter than I would like, but this project fascinates me.

@Quintessence - cloudy orange beer with a modest head retention; yeasty with notes of raisins and apples; a good malt body, assertive and lively, acidic; fruity and sourish, quite dry with more earthy and hay-like notes in the aftertaste

Bottle shared with the Epic. This was a real treat. Aroma of lemon zest, sour oak, and grass. Pours hazy blonde with a nice filmy head and white lacing. Taste is just amazing and intense. Lemon zest, citrus, oak, mineral, and lemongrass. Perfectly tart without heavy acidity. Nice clean grain finish. This is a damn fine Gueuze. Please make more!

Slightly hazy golden colour, slight white head. Aroma of hay, citrus, lemon peel, white wine, berries, pear and redcurrants. Light sour flavour, white wine, wood, horse blanket. Rather dry. Light woody finish, hint of astringency, malts, quite fruity, citrus. Nice and balanced, quite impressed by this American jewel.
(from 37.5cL bottle @ Cantillon Quintessence)

Pours in hazy yellow body with low head. Aroma has light fruity sourness with malty notes. Taste has high short lasting pear sourness with low to medium malty support. Body is full, medium carbonation.

375ml bottle. Hazy pale yellow with a white head. Apple fruitiness coming forth in the aroma. Taste has a lot of buttery malt and a slight harshness to the dry, oaky finish. Less dry and wine-like than many gueuzes. Not quite in Belgiums league, but not far off.
At quintessence. Golden-orange colour with white lace. Fruity, brett aroma. Fruity, sweet, sour taste. Light to medium body.

@ Quintessence - amber,yellow color with a fizzy small, fast vanishing head. Decent aromas of fruit, berries and apple, lambic yeast, a bit wooden. Hay, grass, wood, apples and grapes - not as acidic as the Cantillon Geuzes, lacks a little depth, but has a fantastic balance. Soft lively carbonation, adding to the refreshing character.

At Cantillon Quintessence.
APPEARANCE: clear blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: sour, wood, dry, fruity.
TASTE: sour, dry, wood, decent.
Bottle sample @Cantillon Quintessence 2014. Cloudy light orange, white head. Aroma is sour and a bit fruity. Taste sour and bit fruity.
@ Cantillon Quintessence. Amber colour, white foam. Sour aroma with notes of green apples and lemon. Lactic sourness with light sweet notes. Very good.

Bottle at Quintessence 2014. Pours light golden with a nice steady head. Explosively fresh nose of hay, butter flower, some lactic notes, lemon zeste and a bit of funky yeast. Love the refined body and the fizzly carbonation on the tip of the tongue - makes one think of fine champagne. Light body with a buttery effect, overall very mellow. Very nice beer.
2014.04 - Cantillon Quintessence 2014 - neus : lambiek, zure appeltjes, zelfs een notie van porto/sherry - smaak - geuzeachtig met iets bitterder nasmaakje

Hazy yellow with virtually no head. Aroma is funky cheese, vinegar, barnyard. Light bodied, surprisingly sweet to start on the palate, then little tartness comes out through the long dry finish. Taste is aged cheddar, dried fruits, tart citrus peel.

Sample, night of the great thirst. wow, is this a real gueuze? Bright orange, small tiny bubbles, persistent head. Nose of peach, sour apple, bright lemon juice, grass, hay and leather. taste is crisp and light, dry mouthfeel amazing layers of flavor. This is remarkable. if only it was as available as 3 F gueuze.

At nacht van de grote dorst 
Smells funky and oak
Good carbo . Nicely sour , full , buttery aspect , intense . Nice
From bottle at De Nacht van de Grote Dorst 2014. Cloudy golden, small head. Lemony nose and flavours, woody and cellar flavours. Dry. True to style.

375ml bottle in a teku. Pours hazy golden with a small, white head. Aroma strong of funky/tart yeast and bacteria, some pale malts, and light oak notes. Flavor the same with an awesome funkiness/sour note. Average texture. A really good beer.

375mL bottle, sent from Gregg657 (thanks a lot, Pete), pours a cloudy golden with tiny white head. Aroma is very subtle, with light lemon, citrus zest, and very light funk. Flavour is very authentically gueuze-like, with lots of barnyard funk, horse blanket, and lemon zest. Almost closer to an unblended lambic, with a wet wood / cardboard finish. Could use a little more liveliness on the tongue. Still, excellent American gueuze interpretation.
Bottle courtesy of jtclockwork shared at the January 2014 tasting in Santa Cruz. Piney lemony aroma. Flavor has sour white grapefruit and tree sap, heavy citrus and firm acidity. Nice.
Slightly hazy orange pour with minimal head. Aroma of citrus peel, vinegar, and apricot. Flavor is sour apricot, woody citrus, and raspberry-like tartness.

April 2013 bottle. Dirty and wild like a Coolship beer should be. Smells fruity and funky, pours clear and golden. Taste is complex with a touch of sour up front, but a long finish thats more funk than tart. Good stuff.

Bottle thanks to a trade! Pours a slightly hazy pale gold with a white head that dissipates quickly and completely. Aroma has notes of cheese, light tart fruits a good amount of funk and some light grains. Flavor has the same cheese note with some light sour notes, a touch of acid and a bit of funkiness.
Hazy golden straw colored pour. Small white head that quickly fades. Not much lacing. Sour aroma of fruit, barnyard, and yeast. Taste is a tart fruit, almost a rhubarb. Lemon and orange. Spicy.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2014 Pours hazy yellowish golden with thick white head. Smell is fruity, yeasty, funk and bourbon.  Taste is dry, fruity, tart, funk with bourbon on the finish.  Super complex and smooth.  Medium body, heavy carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2014 Bottle shared by LeninCat @ Armins. Light yellow pour with a slight white head. Funky and slight cheese nose. Taste is soft and simple, not sour at all. Slightly bitter in the finish.

Edit - enjoying a full bottle of this without the pallet fatigue of a big tasting and bumping my scores up a bit. Very subtle sourness missed previously. Really nice.
Bottle. Light lemon colored pour, no carbonation and an aroma of very funky citrus. Flavor is extremely funky lemon, dirty socks and lingering barnyard on the aftertaste.
Bottle. Pours a clear yellow. Aroma is funky, really good funk. Flavor is lemon funk, not overly sour. Very unique, very good.

Bottle - Pours light amber with next to no head. Nose is dry, sweaty funk, lemon, grapefruit, and a little plasticy funk. Taste is citrus rind, dry pale malt, lemon, medium tartness, some graininess in the finish, along with some vinegar. Thinnish, a bit slick, with medium carbonation. Really good stuff.

Bottle thanks to Luke. Pale yellow with a champagne like head. Aroma is light fruit, funky cheese, vinegar, and vanilla. Very lively mouthfeel with a light body. Finish is exceptionally dry. Flavors of blue cheese, green apple, pepper to name a few. Cool beer!

Hazy orange-golden pour with a white head. The aroma has some nice barnyard funk notes as well as some peaches and a light bit of tartness. The flavor is very similar. I get some nice sour peach and orange notes as well as some good cheesy funk, vaguely similar to that funky notes you get in the true Belgian lambics. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bottle thanks to jbportland. .Pour is light gold with a thin white head..Nose is bugs, oak, cobwebs, grape, funk, basement, citrus...Taste is nice light citrus, funk, cheese, bugs, spice, cobwebs, some dryness, basement. .

375mL cork and cage. Pours orange gold with a champagne like white head and carbonation. Aroma is citrus, hay, pepper. Taste is sour with flavors of citrus acidity, grapefruit pith bitterness, vanilla oak and a bit of earthy funk. Finishes dry and slightly bitter.

Bottle 375ml. Thx J-M.
Pours light golden with almost no head. Aroma is of fruits, barnyard, citrus. Taste is of fruits, barnyard. Good sourness. Acidity. Slight bitterness. Palate: Light body. Mouth puckering. Overall: Refreshing (acidity). A bit too rough for me. Not so smooth.

Courtesy of my bro in law and sis in common-law from Portland. Nice pop to the cork. Poured into a Tired Hands wine glass. Great fruity aroma. Mouthfeel is light and champagne carbonation. Taste is very fruity with straw lemon orange strawberry and mild funk. Overall an excellent sour. I really enjoyed it a lot. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from brewery, light and funky, not as complex
As the Belgians but the style is dead on, USA USA USA

Pretty good gueze. Pour is a flattish straw color with some cloudyness. Aroma is wet barrel, funk, sour milk, peaches, melon, and light medicinal funkyness. Taste is heavily tart with some light sweetness. An odd acrid bile taste in the finish keeps this from being great. Still a good gueze but doesnt quite live up to the Belgians.

Fobab 2013 Rate #1:
From a dang bottle
Pours a hazy yellow with a good head and nice lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is very funky, socks, laundry, & barnyard on that tip. Its also got some light oak and sour cherry character. 

The flavor is tart, oaky, & earthy. The sourness is well finessed and not harsh at all. The beer has a lot of tart fruit and some brininess.  
Interesting and pretty damned good.

13th November 2013Tasting at Bruces Pad. Thanks to Sour hunter supreme - Paulio. Cloudy gold beer with a small white head. Palate is dry snd crisp. Woody gueuzey sourness with a touch of dried fruits. Mild minerals and a dry finish. Woody sour linger. Not bad.

Bottle via trade. It pours hazy golden with a small white head. The nose is floral, wood, light must, hay, touch of blue cheese and faint spice. The taste is crisp, tart, orange sherbet, apricot, peach, wood, light acidity, lemonade, orange chewits, leaf and green apple with a crisp, tart finish. Medium body and fine, fizzy carbonation. Thankfully not too acidic. Crisp, fruity and well-balanced. Really, rather tasty.

Bottle cheers to Paul. Hazy vibrant orange with not much of a head. Nose is big sherbert, macadamia nuts, a big raspberry tart presence and some lemon zest. Taste is a touch sugary, cherry tartness, hay, barnyard like, dirt and sherbert. Fairly sweet. Solid stuff

Bottle shared at my 5K tasting at Bruces pad, big thanks to Paolo for this one, 13/11/13.
Hazed golden orange with a moderate off white head.
Nose is smokey citric dipped straw, bitter orange, lemon rind, dank wood, musty leaves.
Taste comprises dank straw, citric tarteness, burnt lemon rind, orange peel, cobwebs, light dry rot notes.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, zingy citric burn in the finish.
Most Decent.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Bottle from the brewery picked up by HopasaurusRex, thanks for the hookup Todd!
Pours a slightly hazy light yellow color with a smallish white head that quickly dissipates to swirls of foam on top. Aromas of lemony tartness and barnyard funk. The flavor is quite tart with huge tooth enamel dissolving properties. Lemons and earthy funk make up most of the flavor here. The finish is fairly dry but leaves a lingering tartness on the palette. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a tart puckering mouthfeel. Tart lightly funky brew thats light and refreshing like lemonade on a hot day. I enjoyed it, Im glad I got to try it.

From 10/17 notes. 375ml bottle, bottled 4/13 batch. Pours hazy golden straw yellow with 1 finger head. Nose is tart oak, apple, citrus, awesome funk, barnyard, hayfield. Mouthfeel is carbonated, medium bodied, crisp. Taste is woody tart citrus, lemon, hay, green apple, brett, big oak barrel, big funk, complex. Finish is sour, dry, oak, lemon, orange rind. Absolutely in the top tier of American gueuze-style. Awesome.
375ml at my place with Patrick Taylor Thomas. Aroma is sour acidic, tangy tart, beautiful. Taste is tangy citrus medium acidity, very nice light sour. Delicious Gueuze. Love it.

Superb tart tasting American gueuze. Bought 0.33 cl bottle at gueuze festival near Brussels. 

 

 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark yellow, quickly dissipating head.

Smell funky and tart, amazingly close to an authentic Belgian Geueze. 

Taste funk and tangerine, tart. 

Smooth and easy drinking.

Hands down my favorite American Gueuze, better than Beat by a lot.
An American legit gueuze, wtf? Tart lemony grassy, lightly crisp maltiness. Another solidly above-average Allagash sour.

12.7oz shared by jstax at Natifest 2013. Mostly hazy pale yellow orange color. Minimal off-white head. Loose lace. Medium body. soft, tingly carbonation, dry finish. Nice, stronger sour taste. Awesome oak. Moderate bacterial flavors. Awesome American gueuze.

An incredible pour of vibrant and rich golden orange/amber with tons of character. A tiny head on this one with a burnt orange yeast dropping as the bottle goes completely on end. Nice light carbonation going on inside with a settling head. Hot damn this beer smells good and funky. Incredible tart citrus/grape and wild earthy goodness getting down in a perfect harmonized carpet-cutting, roof burning, shakedown. 100% funk, pure tart amazing lambic. The funk continues, a beautiful palate pleaser of tart and funky lemon, white grape, oak notes, hearty earthy grains, and a slight acidic tone. Its the perfect balance of tartness that soaks in across the whole palate all the way back to the throat leaving you wanting another draw.

375 ml bottle shared by JStax- thanks a ton, Jeremy! These Coolships were a massive surprise. Pours a cloudy, pale yellow with a tiny white ring. Aroma of sweat, lemon, leather, herbs, oak, grains, and some cheesy funk. Flavor of lemon, grass and herbs, leather, oak, cheese, a bit of yogurt, and dusty grains. Light-bodied, with a dry, tart mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Flavor has more tartness than the aroma. Really nice. Impressed with this line so far.
375 ml bottle thanks to lukaduke. Thanks! Pours a hazy yellow with a white head of foam. The aroma has a musty, white wine tartness. Tastes very sour and musty. Delicious.
sampled at NatiFest 2013 - sour nose. fruity. dry. not my style. space to let me rate.
Bottle. Poured a hazy golden color with a small sized head. Funky, citrus, brett, tart, and fruity. Nice tart finish.

pour @ THE festival, maine. unclear pale golden with a nice white head, good retention and lacing. funk-plenty, honeyed grains without their sweetness, cheese, pepper, herbs, flowers and yeast. bright carbonation, light body, not completely dry - bottle ageing will benefit this beer. much enjoyed!

Generous pour from bottle @ The Festival (Portland). Hazy yellow with a small white head and little lacing. Aroma is grassy with brettanomyces, lemon, wood, light barnyard and cheesy notes. Taste is slightly sweet with grass, brettanomyces, lemon, cheese, light barnyard and moderate sourness. Light to medium body. Moderately dry. Average carbonation. This is not a true Belgian Gueuze, its not far from that. Pretty good!

375 ml shared by adnielsen. Thanks, dude. Pours a golden hazy pour, touch of darkness, with some haziness, good frothy whitish head dies to a film, laces ok. Aromas are tart, lemon, and wild. Mellow oak, firm sourness, some farmhouse, straw, and bigger lemony lactic presence. Initial is medium bodied, big lemon, some florals, big lactic presence, yogurt and sourness. Some florals, melon, and straw. Firm oak, bready malt into the middle. Some sweet tarts, white grape, and more oak. Backend is tart, dry, firmly constructed. Wild, sour, and oaky. Dry, a bit fuzzy, and tannic into the finish. More sour, white grape and lemon and lingering flavors. Tasty, sustained sourness. No acidity but rich sour lactic and citrusy elements. Oak, a bit of nutty earth, firm sour fruit. Tasty and well constructed. Nice one here!
bottle served at "the festival". rustic. dry. grassy. some old cellar funk. lemon. pretty good.

Bottle. Thanks to adnielsen for sharing. Pours a cloudy golden orange color with white head.  Barnyard, funk, cheese aromas.  Funky, cheesy, barnyard flavors.  A killer beer.  Big thanks to Aaron!!  This beer kills.

375 ml bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head.  The aroma is tart citrus, acidic, woody, funk and perhaps a touch of sweat.  The flavor has tart citrus, hints of caramel, acidic, woody, hints of spice and funk.  On the dry side; a very interesting beer.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured cloudy golden color with an average to large frothy white head that was lasting with good lacing. Moderate to heavy sour, floral, yeast aroma. Medium to full body with a dry texture with soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sour flavor with a medium sour finish of moderated to long duration. This is a solid for style beer.

Bottle. Smells like Resurgam! Nah, just kidding. Pours a clear amber color with a light white head. Acidic lemon and white grape notes in the nose. Light mouthfeel. Grape, funk, brett like florals, and lemon citrus notes in the flavor. Ends with a lingering funkiness and dry. Some lingering bitterness as well. Interesting but not overly exciting.

375 ml bottle to snifter (BIG thanks to alexsdad06). Looks good; a cloudy gold with thin white lacing. Smells good too; cheese, barnyard, funk, and sweaty socks (in a good way). Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel. Good beer.
Bottle snagged during RBWG 2013. Hazy golden pour with a nice off-white head. Funk, barnyard, lemons, slight fruitiness, and definite tart in the aroma and flavor. Tasty!
From Ltdan.  Jesus this is good.  Wow.  Dry and dusty, lemons, earth, oak, barnyard flavors, sour, soft, yeasty...just damn freaking awesome.  Id drink this any day.

Batch 3:

Wow, this was delicious!!  Extremely cheesy, as if it has been aged for 10 yrs.  Incredible balance between sour and funk.  Probably the best American Geuze i have ever had

Batch 3, I think (bottled ~6/2012). Big, bold, cheesy aroma. Barnyard funk, hay, horse blankets. Sour and citric. Flavor packs a real punch. Reminds me of an aged Cantillon (*not* 3F) gueuze.

I couldn't stop drinking this. Absolutely delicious; hands down the best batch yet.

Bottle, 03/31/2013. Pours hazy golden orange, small head, dies down to a flat surface. Aroma is tart, sour white fruit, bitter grapefruit, lemon, funky bleu cheese and wood. Taste is green apples, grapes, nice citrus component, sweet and tart, funky finish, oak. Maybe just a touch of acetone that throws me off near the end. Light, smooth palate. Really nice interpretation of the style, tasty, it grew on me more as the beer warmed.

Bottletnx to Greg. Pours pale clear golden with a nice off white head. Aroma is rich fruity perry sour a bit sweet funky sour. Flavor is funky sour acidy acetone slightly sweet fruity a bit bitter. Finishes tart astringent fruity.

bottle from the grand tasting, happy to have caught it .. . pours out tan .. . mild foam, spots of small lacing .. . has a kinda compost quality, fruits and farm like flavours .. . an interesting beer, but too dirty or rustic to be great .. . . i was happy to wake up this morning

Bottle shared at RBWG.  Thanks to whomever brought this.  Pours a lightly hazy urine straw yellow.  Nose is nutty, sweet, light oak,  Flavor is buttery oak, light funk, hay.  Not much going on here, sadly.

Bottle. Pours hazy gold. Slight head with no lacing. Aroma is big, funky and tart. Taste is the same. Not very complex, but very pleasant and excellently sour. Slightly puckering but not overwhelming.
Got this one at the brewery, enjoyed as part of a Christmas sour tasting.  This one was nice and tart, cirrus, fruits.  I prefer the sour brown ales but this was a goody.

Bottle with some heads. Pours murky orange gold with thin non-lasting white head. Notes were super sour: passionfruit, lemons, apple, barn funk and hazy wood tones. Medium carbonation with a lighter body. My favorite allagash next to avance and interlude. Cheers.

Draft @ GABF, Friday session. Pours a hazy, bright-golden color; thin white head. Beautiful, generous aroma, nicely tart and funky, with plenty of tart lemons and saltiness. Medium body; medium-light carbonation; but the bright acidity and tartness keep this lively in the mouth; lemons, salt, sure, with an undercurrent of funk and cheesiness; just an excellent, funky lambic approximation that really comes together nicely. Lightly dry finish: salt and citrus lasting.

Bottle (375 ml) from atrade with rfraga. CShady deep golden, low to medium white head. Fruity aroma with green apples, grapefruit and pineapples, some wood and funky notes. Light to medium bodied, medium to high carbonation. Dry with firm acidity. Quite impressive considering the short time of operation, but still some way to go to compare with the best of the real stuff.

375ml bottle:  This one pours a hazy, dark golden color.  There was a small, fizzy head that didnt linger long.  No lacing either.  Interesting nose.  Definitely funky!  Seems to be sour apple and lemon are the main components.  Maybe some wheat, but its hard to tell.  The taste is definitely a bit sour.  Wheat, lemon and apple notes.  Not much carbonation at all.  There is a smoothness to go along with the tartness.  Very Good!
Served in an Allagash tumbler.  Nose is pretty cheesy and funky. Light acidity. Mild skunk. Quite authentic. Super dry. One of the best American sours. But too skunky.

Shared by Thorpe429 alongside several other Allagash sour/wild ales. Thank you very much, Mike!

The beer appears light golden colored with a thin, wispy head that leaves faint traces of lacing on the glass. The aroma brings some nice funk, along with earth, grass, hay, straw, outdoors, mineral water. Smells very enticing - nicely done. The flavor is clean and refreshing, with a subtle and elegant lactic presence followed by a mildly acetic finish. Not on par with the elite gueuzes from Belgium, but a very nice beer, and undoubtedly one of the better attempts from an American brewery. Light bodied and easy drinking. Overall, this was solid and enjoyable. I would have this again.

Bottle @ home for #5,000! Special thanks to a buddy in Portland, Maine that hooked me up with an all-time favorite. Ive had it on two occasions at GABF, but figured I would do a nice re-review for #5,000. 375mL bottle opens with a mild hiss. Pours a moderately cloudy, yellow orange appearance with a moderate cream colored head. Fairly lactic, tangy, a bit spicy funky, a bit cheesy, mild citrusy aroma. Not as much funk or cheese in the nose that I got during my trips at GABF. More tart than my previous. Just a ton of funk, somewhat spicy, barnyard/hay, woody/herbal. moderate cheese, tangy, fairly oaky flavor with an ultra-funky, moderately sour, lemon, a touch chewy finish. Fantastic, fantastic stuff. It really has a beautiful, rich flavor that Ive tried in very few American sours. FUCK YEAH. (4.6)

GABF 2012. They brought this baby back again?! It was my second favorite last year at the fest and this year it took gold in my book. Huge cheesy funk and barnyard elements along with a very satisfying and refreshing sourness but not overdone by any means on the sourness. So much funky, lacto, stinky character makes this baby one of my all-time new favorites. FUCK YEAH. (4.7)

GABF 2011. Moderate cloudy, light yellow appearance with a white head. Barnyard, moderately tart, light cheesy, lemon citrusy aroma. Tangy, lemon citrusy, cheese, funky, barnyard flavor. Yeah! (4.3)

Multiple pours at GABF 12. Hazy yellow in appearance with a small white head. Funk, cheese, urine, dust, citric acid, and wood in the aroma. Taste is sour fruits, highly refreshing, yet balanced beautifully with funk and wood; big citrus juice, lemon zest, urine, and wax. Light and crisp body with high carbonation. Seriously well-built beer and by far the best example of an American made gueuze I have ever come across. Awesome!

Sampled on 10/12/2012 at GABF. This gueuze pours a slightly hazy light yellow gold color from the tap. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity, sweet, funky and tart. A medium bodied gueuze. The malts are fruity and sweet, tart and funky. The hops are herbal. Decent mild carbonation. Lots of tartness and some funk throughout this beer. Nice balance. Lightly acidic. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly tart.

draft at GABF.
cheese rind and armpit BO bacteria.
black pepper and minerals.
strikingly sour lemon juice.
measured oak.
brightly acidic and tart and juicy.
fluffly wheat character.
very Belgian-like, Im happy to report.

Opened during Sunday Night Football with readbaron and bauermj. This is the 7/27/11 batch. Had the first batch and heard this was better, so Im eager to see how this one is. Pours a cloudy yellow with a fingers worth, head is slightly soapy in appearance. Nose is comprised of pepper and lemon, with the black pepper being the predominate theme. Flavor is similar to the nose with the pepper being more subdued. It gets more balanced as it warms. Light mouthfeel, gentle carbonation, light tartness, and a moderate finish. I like this less than the first batch, the pepper character is too much to overcome. Hopefully future batches are better.

375ml bottle. Courtesy of the nightrider. Thanks Tom... Pours a somewhat hazy apricot orange hue and topped with a quickly reducing white head that results in a ring around the glass... Aroma is geueze like with a barnyardy funk. Somewhat sharp and cheesy but has a genuine lambic-like quality to it... Flavors continue in a similar path with lambic qualities consisting of a mild degree of barnyard funkiness upfront with a decent amount of sourness that shortens up with a semi-sweetness that shortly curtails into a dry effervescent finish. Body is shy of medium with fairly lively carbonation. Could honestly be mistaken for a Belgian lambic, although doesnt live up to the better standards of the style. Still fairly solid especially for an American sour.

Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow with a touch of foam and some side and bottom rising bubbles.  Aromas are sour fruit, young nectarine, berry, dusty, wood and funk. On the palate its comes off ripe and sour with tart bright touches of grapefruit and a beautiful funky rustic dry earthy finish. Damn this is probably the most classic gueuze Ive had from the states.
Strong sour fruit and moderate wood aroma. Hazy dark golden color with a medium white head. Strong sour beginning that fades slowly to the finish. Taste is very complex. Light palate.

Bottle generously shared by Colin (I think).  Cloudy yellow pour.  Tart lemon and citrus notes.  Sour and well balanced.  A nice example of a north-eastern birkenstock take on the traditional Belgium staple...

Bottle... Murky golden ale with no head. The aroma is funky, mega-fruity and ultra-acidic. Medium-bodied with lazy carbonation. The sour, funky flavor also presents bready, fruity notes flanked by moderate bitterness. Finishes woody and lightly bitter. Big-time thanks to ctipping for sharing this bottle with the south Florida crew!

Huge thanks to kiefdog for the share.  Cheers, Kevin!  Pours a hazy gold with a white head.  Nose is oak, vinegar, lemon, some cheese, and big tartness.  Flavor is similar with lemon, lacto, huge tartness, mild cobweb, and huge vinegar.  Starts fruity and dries out very quickly.  Light to medium in body and very gueuzey.

375mL thx to Travlr. Full haze lighter golden. Medium white head. Nose is gueuze like with leather, grapefruit peel, white pepper, curaçao oil and potpourri. Taste is tangy, leathery, lactic, spicy. Girardin and 3F style funk. Very nice. Subtle and clean. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle courtesy of Kirk, thank you sir!  Cloudy yellow orange color, small white head, solid lacing. Aroma of dusty pear skins and light citrus. Taste is softly sour lemon drops, grapefruit, more pronounced sourness toward the finish.  Nice funkiness, very geuze-like.

Pours a hazy gold with no head. Aroma of vinegar, slight cheese, really funky. Taste follows. Really funky. Pretty nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cloudy orange yellow body.  Thin off-white head.  Spotty lacing.  Nose is pleasant with a delicate blend of funk, cheese, hay, lemon, grapefruit.  Flavor is equally pleasant with just a hair less complexity.  Funk and lemon shifts toward the forefront.  Medium to light bodied.  Healthy dose of lactic tartness.  Thoroughly impressed with this "gueuze" offering from Allagash--If they keep up with producing this, I expect this to eventually be considered in the same ballpark as the Drie Fonteinens, Cantillons, Girardins and Tilquins of the world.

[BCTC 12] Hazy dark golden color with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of wood, bacteria, and light red wine vinegar notes. Taste of wood, fruity sweetness, some vinegar notes, and a sour finish.

Pours hazy opaque amber with a thin lasting white head.  Smells of dry malt, some underlying tart/sour hints, some residual sugar traces, coriander notes.  Tastes of tarte fruit, some musky undertones, some hay/floral elements.  Decent.

Bottle. Clear gold pour with thick white head. Aroma is surprisingly authentic, lots of funky sheesy aromas that reminded me quite a bit of Girardin black label. Taste is sour and funky, pretty dry, a tiny bit of oak. Palate has moderate carbonation and is medium bodied. Very tasty and quite well made american lambic - closest to the real thing Ive ever tastes I think.

375ml bottles poured at Lupulin Reunion 2012 at RFD.  Pours a hazy, dark orange with some creamy, white head.  Nose is awesome, grapefruit, grass, hay, cheese, perfume, Brett B, dandelions, bitter greens, lemon.  Flavor is lemon, bright acidity, grass, collard greens, a little powdered lemonade, grapefruit.  Medium bodied, bright, citrus finish.  Really good.

[#1000 Rating & #100 American Rating] thx to Sebletitje for getting to try this one // he got from Jean, the owner of Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas// Big time want // got a full De Ranke tasting glass of this one, during the finish of the first day of the Italian Beer Festival // 37.5 ml bottle bottled on 25/5/2011 // making it slightly over 1 yr old // pours a hazy golden with a sizable head for the style that has some nice lacing going on // aroma is instantly gauze, I didnt know what to expect from a real American gauze, honestly & peraps nationalistically, I expected it to be ok but weaker than the best Belgian counterparts because I believed that the factory had to become saturated y the critters over a long period of time, man was I wrong, smell is delicious, strongly tart, I am getting lots of horse blanket here, brett, touch lambic yeast & hint of pungent citrus // strong farmhouse, barnyard, tartness going on  here in the beginning, touch wood, citrus, strongly tart lemon peel, touch heavier in the finish coming into play, hint of wood, quite horse blanket heavy I a lovely way, going into definitely more acidic territory in the back than Belgian counterparts, the initial  flavours get complimenting, resulting in a nice complexity with strong acidity & a dash of what is getting already quite close to vinegar, maybe dash of apple vinegar, not so much the fruit but a mellowness that encompasses the vinegar, just as with apple vinegar compared to regular one, heavily acidic, brief moment in the end of bitterness, quite interesting, makes me think a bit of a small instance of bitter herbal / farmhouse hops // touch dry & lightly fizzy, touch 3F style in that department, easy going, makes you want to drink more // outstanding, lots of interesting flavours & component, some touch newer to me, on part with the stuff that we make here which may not be that special anymore if the states are filled with this kind of stuff

Many thansk to Jean @ Moeder Lambic for sharing the bottle.
Bottled 05/25/2011.
Dorée, col léger blanc.
Arôme garde tout le bouquet dune bonne gueuze, citronné, houblonné sec avec pas mal dagrumes sur ce léger côté boisé.
En bouche, profile boisé épicé, reste sèche en bouche tout en étant légère et complexe. Profile houblon sec vers du citronné sur un fini rappelant une cour de ferme. Le tout reste sur un brett bien présent et renforce une fin de bouche citrique.

Que dire? phénoménale et concurrençant les grands noms belges du style et devançant un bon nombre.

Arbitrary score 4/5 for Appearance, as nighttime conditions prevented correct assessment. Citric, Bretts, (both floormop and more classical lambick-y), unripe peaches aroma. Surprising, slighlty smoked flavour, phenolic, tarry, with Brett/saddlesoap and lemony finish. Soft texture, specially in the finish, long lasting flavours. Im at a loss as to where the Islay Malt touch might hail from?? Many thanks to Mathieu!

Shared at WTWBA 2012, Brooklyn.  The aroma is farmhouse, sour fruit.  The flavor is just like the aroma, sour fruit especially.  The appearance is a hazy yellow, white head.  The finish is sour fruit, horseblanket.  Decent.
Love the levels of sourness, nice carbonation levels and mouth feel, Tart fruit, oak, grape like character. Dry finish. Great stuff

Bottle shared at WtWBA in Brooklyn 2012. Pours a hazy amber brown body with white head/lacing. Aroma is tart, funk and sour cherry. Mouthfeel is delicate and tart with notes of sour fruit, oak, funk, and light vinegar. Great.
Bottle shared by MikeLovesBeer. This was a pretty intense sour! Smelled a lot like sour tartness mixed with dirty baby diaper. Sort of strange at first but very solid for a sour.

Pours unclear golden orange with almost no head. The delicious aroma brings sweet and tart lambic yeast notes so pleasant. The flavor is really smooth with lighter carbonation and a delicious yeasty backbone with sweet notes that drop to a pleasant smooth pucker.

Pours a hazy gold color with a white head.  Really just a decent aroma.  A surprising cork note along with moderate funk qualities (mostly feet and grass).  A decent bit of oak and actually a bit of sweet wheat smell.  The flavor has a more pronounced funk to it.  Lots of must, sweat, and grass.  Prominent oak flavors with only a light tartness and lemon peel.
Bottle thanks to Gabe!  Funky fruity aromas.  Barnyard and tart fruit flavors.   Overall a pretty impressive sour.
Lemon and kumquat on the nose with citrus blossom, very floral aroma.  Pours a cloudy gold.  Funky and earthy with lemon citrus and more earthy funk than lactic sour.  Finishes dry and Bretty.
On draft.  Poured a hazy yellow color.  Lactic funk, with a slight oak flavor.  Tart.  Different and nice.

On tap at GABF. Pours with a hazed golden hued body with a small white head that lasts. Lots of funk in the aroma, estery, fruity and sour. Flavors show a fleeting bit of fruity sweetness, strawberry, estery, funk and oak tannins. Good sour, lively bubbles, dry, great!

Bottle shared at a tasting at my house. Pours slightly cloudy gold with white head. Nose/taste of cheese, basement funk, yeast, lemon breads and lightly tart lemon. Medium body. Mild tartness. Some barley notes in finish.

GABF 2011.  Clear light gold with a nice small head.  Smells like a sour belgian with oak, grapes, apple, and other light fruit. Taste is pretty sour as well, with light fruit and chardonnay oak having the biggest impact.  Slightly herbal and citrusy, with an ok body and more sour than Im comfortable with.

(375ml bottle)  Pours a hazy golden body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of egg whites, barnyard, spoiled yogurt, lemon, and berries.  Flavor of sour lemon, light vegetal, yogurt, and earth with a dry oak finish.

Appearance:  Pours a hazy pastel gold with a thin cap of white.

Aroma: Light tart funk.

Taste: Bitter metallic funk,  cactus cooler . Finishes tart.

Mouthfeel: Chalky. Modest carbonation.

Overall: Tasty and tart, will probably develop greatly.

Pours hazy yellow with white head on tap at GABF.  Aroma has big notes of cheesy, barnyard, dirty basement funk, tons of it, with a nice balance of lemon lacto, and some other nice fruity notes.  Taste is big funky, cheesy, dusty funk, some slight sweet biscuit and fruit notes going into a nice tart, lemony finish.  Really good stuff, the highlight of the fest for me.

sample at GABF on 9/20/11.  golden pour with a small white head.  grapes, funk and sour on the nose.  feels slightly off a tad...  medium body with a general tartness and lactic acid. dry finish. light oak.

Bottle at GABF. No idea this was a "gueuze." Pours an attractive gold with a sticky head that thins out. Nose is quite tart and fruity, light barnyard and cherries. Odd mix. On tasting, it is more bitter/harsh than expected. Perhaps it needs some more time to really level out. Refreshingly tart and fruity, though. Some tropical fruit notes. Okay.

A few tasters (several actually- yummy stuff) at GABF. Poured a hazy yellow with a thin foamed head. Nose of a nice funky sour with straw and leather aromas. Balanced tartness, rounded edges, only lightly tangy. Well carbed. Lingering finish. Lovely example..

On tap at GABF.  Cloudy golden in color with a small white head.  The aroma is like Cantillon or 3F Gueuze - funky with great complex barnyard notes.  Excellent flavor, complex and up there with good gueuzes.  Funky with hay and spice.  Medium sourness.  Maybe lacking the depth of the great examples, but thats sort of nitpicking.  Medium-bodied and biting on the mouthfeel with lively carbonation.  A great American blend of spontaneously fermented beers, something you dont see all that often as of yet.

GABF 2011 - fuck yes - lovely, balanced nose of lacto tartness, oaky tannins, barnyardy Brett and cheesy funk - flavor is tart lacto up front, dry and oaky middle and lingering funky Brett on the tail end - lingering, tingly acidity - nothing too intense, avoiding the pitfalls of most American made sours - subtle but complex at the same time - love the shit out of this.

On tap @ BCTC 2011.  Hazy gold, white head.  Nose is cheesy with lemon, horseblanket, unripe berries & hay.  Flavor is lemon pith, earthy funk, woody & tannic.  Ends up being a bit more bitter than I would like, but this project fascinates me.

Pouring from their table during the festival at BCTC.  Pours a lightly hazed gold with a medium sized white head.  Big cheesy brett, funky wood and acid on the nose.  Cheesy and funky, soft sweetness.  Toast and funk, light wood.  Excellent funky brett finish.
#2800, BCTC 2011, First beer of the session, lasted about 15 minutes. Pours a pale blonde with mild carbonation. . funky, vinegar, acidic, light lemon. Dry white wine like characteristics. Good
Bottle at Jacobs. Pours a slightly hazy pale amber with no head. Smells of wood and dust. Sweet with a slight sourness. Some woody aromas. Light bodied. Medium to soft carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2013 Bottle at Mes Tasting. Cloudy, yellow gold pour with a slight film. Big funk aroma, lots of sour notes, maybe some lemon. Lightly sweet, grassy, pretty sour, faint fruits. Light body with fine to average carbonation. Woody, lightly dry finish, plenty sour. (3.9)< br/>Bottle shared at Bruces in London - thanks to Paul. Solid offering. Easy drinking. (4.0)

Bottle 375ml.Unclear medium to dark yellow color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy dry barnyard, grape, sour, fruity, wood, barnyard, malty. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate acidic with a average to long duration, dry. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100624]
Bottled. An unclear golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of vinegar, wine, and citrus. The flavor is sour with notes of lemon, malt, and lacto acid, leading to a tart finish.
37.5 cL bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is dry barnyard, wooden and leathery. Citrusy, acidic and dry wooden. Barnyard. Dry and acidic finish.
This is one funky ass brew.  Smells a bit like lemons in a used diaper.  Flavor, thankfully, is a bit more nuanced, medium tart lemons and citrus.  Crazy stuff.

cloudy yellow, no head.
citrussy dry aroma. balanced. nice.
flavor is very well balanced sour and faint citrussy, no off flavors that i could detect, ends bitter and slightly grapefruity. very well tasting. if anything a little too bitter, but a great sour. refreshing.

Tasting at PapsøCloudy blond color. Like the other Coolship, the aroma of this beer lingers between the puckery and the ass smell; manure and lemon. It has an astringent mouthfeel, with strong citrusy presence (grapefruit peel), without the necessary Bretts; dry finish. It can be enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2012 Bottle 37,5 cl. Courtesy of madsberg. Pours a cloudy and opaque golden with a small off-white head. Dirty barnyard aroma, very dry and tart. Medium body, tart fruit and lots of barnyard and funk. Dry and astringent finish. Lovely. 230410

Light golden pour with a light white head.  
Aroma is sour hay, very earthy with a bit of farmhouse and leather.  
Sour in the mouth with a light earthiness and some more leather and barnyard.  Nice, a little thin, but a nice Gueuze overall
Hazy golden with a medium white head. Sour aroma with lemons, grape and barnyard. The quite sour flavour had leather, barnyard, lemons, earth and hay. Finished sour.

Bottle on Liedekerke Station after De Nacht van de Grote Dorst 2010.Cloudy amber - white head. Gooseberries, light barley notes, wooden, sourness, very smooth body, acid, citric, leather, barnyard, earthy. Nice.
Bottle. No head. Dark yellow body. Acidic lemon aroma. Fruity nutty lemon acidic flavor with low carbonation and a short aftertaste.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense white head. Dense grape and sourness in the aroma. Has a light tarty and earthy touch. Flavour of earth, leather and light barnyard. Very sour. MEdium to full bodied. Very sour and grapy end.

Bottle at Nacht van de Grote Dorst 2010.
Cloudy golden coloured with a small white head.
Fruity and light acidic aroma of berries and oak.
Fruity and light acidic flavour with notes of berries and oak.
Tart finish.
